items.title: Why you can’t just repair your phone in the US to avoid Trump tariffs
items.summary:
- New tariffs in the US are expected to increase costs for new smartphones and repairs.
- Repair companies, like iFixit, anticipate higher parts prices but repairs will still be cheaper than buying new devices.
- Major smartphone parts are largely sourced from outside the US, triggering significant tariff costs of over 100% for China and up to 26% for India.
- Tariffs may increase demand for repairs and refurbishment, making repair more viable due to high new device costs.
- Repair shops are preparing for a 20% increase in parts costs.
- Secondhand device marketplaces like Swappa are likely to see increased sales as consumers look for alternatives to new devices.

items.title: Where have all the headphones gone on public transport? The noise is eating into my soul | Adrian Chiles
Two visions within Trump world are battling for primacy. Which will win?
items.author: Ben Davis
items.summary:
- The second Trump administration is facing chaos with unclear objectives and significant policy changes.
- Major cuts to federal capacity and an unprecedented tariff regime are focal points of the administration's strategy.
- Competing ideological factions, national conservatism and tech capital, are vying for influence over Trump’s policies.
- Tariffs are viewed differently: as a means to boost US manufacturing, raise revenue, or negotiate concessions from other countries.
- The clash of visions raises concerns about the implications for American workers, with the potential for economic crisis and reduced state capacity.

items.title: EU to Build AI Gigafactories in €20bn Push to Catch Up with US and China
items.summary:
- The EU plans to invest €20bn to create new AI gigafactories for developing advanced AI models.
- The initiative aims to enhance Europe’s competitiveness against AI leaders like the US and China.
- The commission envisions constructing three to five gigafactories costing €3-5bn each, capable of hosting over 100,000 AI processors.
- The strategy includes amending the AI Act to possibly simplify regulations to support innovation.
- Criticism has arisen regarding reconsideration of the AI Act, which is still pending full application until 2027.

items.title: Revealed: Big tech’s new datacentres will take water from the world’s driest areas
Online suicide forum investigated under new UK digital safety laws
items.summary:
- Ofcom has launched its first investigation under the new UK digital safety laws into an online suicide forum for potential breaches of the Online Safety Act.
- The UK regulators are assessing whether the forum failed to implement adequate measures to protect users from illegal content, including encouragement of suicide.
- Tech platforms face fines of up to £18m or 10% of global revenue, with Ofcom also able to block access to sites in extreme cases.
- The forum has been linked to at least 50 deaths in the UK and is reported to have tens of thousands of members discussing methods of suicide.
- New obligations under the Online Safety Act require all services to implement safeguards against illegal material.

items.title: Bafta games awards 2025: full list of winners
UK creating ‘murder prediction’ tool to identify people most likely to kill
items.summary:
- The UK government is developing a "murder prediction" programme to identify potential killers using personal data.
- The project, initially called the "homicide prediction project", is now named "sharing data to improve risk assessment".
- Campaigners criticize the project as "chilling and dystopian", expressing concerns about bias against minority and low-income groups.
- The initiative was discovered by the pressure group Statewatch through Freedom of Information requests.
- Data from individuals without criminal convictions may be used, including info on self-harm and domestic abuse, though officials deny this.
- The project aims to analyze offender characteristics to enhance risk assessments of serious crimes.

items.title: An easy to read and interpret title for the article as a string.
items.summary:
- The installation features a lab-grown 'mini-brain' of the late musician Alvin Lucier, creating music posthumously.
- The project, titled Revivification, was created by a team of artists and scientists who collaborated with Lucier before his death in 2021.
- The mini-brain responds to neural signals, producing sounds through 20 brass plates in a gallery setting.
- Lucier's work incorporated brainwaves into music as early as 1965, and he contributed by donating his blood for the project.
- The installation raises questions about artificial intelligence, creativity, and the ethical implications of such technology in the arts.

items.title: Meta blocks livestreaming by teenagers on Instagram
items.summary:
- Meta expands safety measures for teenagers on Instagram, blocking livestreaming for under-16s without parental permission.
- New rules also require parental consent for disabling image blurring of suspected nudity in direct messages.
- Instagram teen accounts used by 54 million under-18s globally, with 90% of users aged 13-15 retaining default restrictions.
- Similar restrictions are being applied to teen accounts on Facebook and Messenger, starting in the US, UK, Australia, and Canada.
- Changes are part of compliance with the UK's Online Safety Act aimed at protecting children from harmful content.

items.title: Ex-Google boss Eric Schmidt buys £42m London mansion
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Eric Schmidt, former CEO of Google, purchased a £42m mansion in Holland Park, London.
- The mansion is a Grade II-listed property that also includes mews houses.
- The property was previously sold for £36.2m in 2022.
- Schmidt plans to rent out the mansion, joining many wealthy Americans investing in London real estate.
- American buyers accounted for 9.3% of overseas property purchases, surpassing Chinese buyers.
- The UK saw a record number of US citizens applying for UK citizenship last year.
- Despite some high-profile sales, overall activity in London’s housing market is slowing, with a drop in sales above £5m compared to previous years.

items.title: UK Home Office loses attempt to keep legal battle with Apple secret
items.summary:
- The UK lost an attempt to keep the details of a legal battle with Apple away from the public.
- The investigatory powers tribunal rejected the Home Office's bid to withhold details related to the case.
- The case involves a challenge by Apple regarding technical capability notices under the Investigatory Powers Act.
- The Home Office claimed that revealing details would damage national security, but the judges disagreed.
- Apple received a technical capability notice demanding access to its Advanced Data Protection service, which it rejected.
- The tribunal's judgment may allow for public elements in future hearings, but some restrictions remain.
- Media organizations had previously been barred from hearings regarding the case.

items.title: Private Footage review – found-footage study of apartheid takes the split-screen route
items.summary:
- Janaína Nagata’s documentary is a detective-style investigation into apartheid.
- The film starts with 19 minutes of homemade travelogue footage revealing the juxtaposition of joyful scenes with the reality of apartheid.
- Uses split-screen to compare the old footage with modern web searches to uncover the history behind the images and identify key figures, including Hendrik Verwoerd, the architect of apartheid.
- The film blends archival material with contemporary media but can feel repetitive for those familiar with South African history.
- Critique of the film highlights its narrow focus and lack of broader sociopolitical context, describing it as an intriguing but limited montage experiment.

items.title: So you want to go to the USA? Are you sure? Here’s how to prepare your machines for Trumpistan | First Dog on the Moon
We have more data on ourselves than ever before. But can we really track our way into happiness?
items.author: Samantha Floreani
items.summary:
- The author explores personal mood tracking and how it can influence perceptions of happiness.
- Self-tracking is facilitated by digital tools, but raises questions about privacy and data commodification.
- The article critiques the trend of quantifying life as potentially harmful and suggests alternatives to self-optimization.

items.title: Which celebrities are lying about their height? This website’s done the research
items.summary:
- The article explores the community around [Celebheights.com](https://www.celebheights.com/), a website dedicated to estimating the heights of celebrities based on various data sources.
- Celebheights was launched in 2004 and gained popularity after being featured on the podcast *Mystery Show* in 2015.
- Notable celebrity height disputes discussed include Mariah Carey and Brendan Fraser, showcasing the range of community-driven commentary and debate on the website.

items.title: ‘Profiting from misery’: how TikTok makes money from child begging livestreams
Meta and Pinterest believed to have donated to Molly Russell charity
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Meta and Pinterest have reportedly donated to the Molly Rose Foundation, which advocates for internet safety.
- The foundation was established in memory of Molly Russell, who died by suicide in 2017 after exposure to harmful content on social media.
- Donations from Meta and Pinterest began in 2024 and are expected to continue for several years, but specific amounts are not disclosed.
- The Russell family stated they would not accept compensation for Molly's death and are focusing on advocacy instead.
- These donations come amid growing scrutiny of social media's impact on children's mental health.

items.title: ‘I didn’t start out wanting to see kids’: are porn algorithms feeding a generation of paedophiles – or creating one?
Trump extends deadline for TikTok sale to non-Chinese buyer to avoid ban
items.summary:
- Donald Trump announced an extension of the TikTok ban deadline by 75 days.
- The new deadline follows a previous delay made on January 19, moving it to mid-June.
- ByteDance, TikTok's parent company, stated discussions are ongoing with the US government regarding the app's future.
- Trump met with potential buyers for TikTok, including Oracle, Blackstone, Amazon, Walmart, and others.
- TikTok has 170 million users in the US, making it a highly valuable asset.
- Trump suggested trade tariff negotiations with China could be linked to a TikTok deal.

items.title: Australia’s social media ban is attracting global praise – but we’re no closer to knowing how it would work
items.summary:
- The Netflix show *Adolescence* has renewed calls for social media bans globally, particularly in the UK, urging similar measures as Australia.
- Australia's government describes its under-16 social media ban as “world-leading,” receiving praise from major media outlets like *Time*.
- Critics, including mental health and LGBTQ+ groups, raised concerns during the bill's rushed review process, which lasted only one day despite over 15,000 submissions.
- The ban is set to come into effect in December 2025, but details on its implementation remain unclear as trials of age-assurance technology are ongoing.
- A major report by Age Check Certification Scheme (ACCS) is due soon, but preliminary findings will not be released publicly.
- The government faces challenges regarding compliance from social media platforms, particularly regarding exemptions for YouTube that have created discontent among other platforms like TikTok and Meta.
- Approximately 80% of children under 13 use social media, mostly through YouTube, complicating the understanding of platform usage among this age group.
- Digital rights groups are notably absent from the advisory board overseeing the trial, raising further questions about the trial's integrity and execution.

items.title: South of Midnight review – beautiful surfaces can’t hide thin gameplay
items.summary:
- South of Midnight offers a magical-realist tale set in a hurricane-ravaged American deep south.
- The protagonist, Hazel, is a Weaver, capable of battling spirits and traversing a richly detailed world.
- The game boasts impressive visuals and a vibrant soundtrack but suffers from thin gameplay mechanics reminiscent of older titles.
- The linear platforming and combat lack depth compared to recent games like God of War, resulting in a less engaging experience.

items.title: US authors’ copyright lawsuits against OpenAI and Microsoft combined in New York with newspaper actions
items.summary:
- Twelve US copyright cases against OpenAI and Microsoft have been consolidated in New York despite opposition from most authors and news outlets involved.
- The US judicial panel's transfer order aims to streamline proceedings and eliminate inconsistent rulings, joining cases by authors like Ta-Nehisi Coates, Michael Chabon, and the New York Times.
- Centralisation is justified by shared factual questions regarding the alleged unauthorized use of copyrighted works to train AI models like ChatGPT and Microsoft’s Copilot.
- There are ongoing lawsuits against Meta for similar issues, with allegations of using a “shadow library” to train AI.
- Amazon announced a new AI feature for Kindle, generating recaps for book series, raising concerns about the accuracy of AI-generated content.

items.title: Clickbait titles and cliffhangers: the mini TV serials capturing phone audiences
items.summary:
- Vertical dramas, originating in China, are short, smartphone-friendly episodic content predicting a market worth of $14bn by 2027.
- Viewers are attracted by engaging clickbait titles and cliffhangers, with apps offering few free episodes before subscription.
- The genre is appealing for its escapism and quick entertainment, especially among women ages 20 to 60 dealing with personal challenges.
- The format provides consistent work for actors amidst industry cutbacks, often filmed quickly and in few days.
- Content Republic aims to produce 400 verticals annually for both domestic and international audiences, highlighting the genre's growth.

items.title: Mario Kart World: hands-on with Nintendo’s crucial Switch 2 launch game
items.summary:
- Nintendo introduces Mario Kart World as the flagship launch title for the Switch 2, featuring 24 racers and 60 characters.
- The game incorporates an exploration element, shifting from closed circuits to an open-world format reminiscent of Forza Horizon.
- Players can engage in two modes: Grand Prix and Knockout Tour, the latter having a battle-royale-style gameplay.
- Initial impressions highlight the game's polished playability and potential loss of intimate racing chaos due to wider tracks.

items.title: TikTok ban deadline looms in US amid last-minute takeover bids
items.summary:
- The deadline for TikTok to divest or sell to a non-Chinese owner is 5 April.
- Donald Trump stated his administration is “very close” to a deal for TikTok.
- Potential buyers include Amazon and venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz.
- Trump hinted at potentially lessening tariffs if ByteDance agrees to a sale.
- ByteDance claims divesting TikTok is not feasible due to legal and commercial reasons.
- The push to ban TikTok began in 2020, focusing on national security concerns.
- Congress previously voted overwhelmingly to ban the app, and a deadline was established by the US Supreme Court.
- There are ongoing discussions involving multiple investors, including Oracle and Blackstone.

items.title: Blanket ban on teen smartphone use ‘potentially detrimental’, says academic
items.author: Amy Orben
items.summary:
- A leading academic from the University of Cambridge, Amy Orben, argues that blanket bans on teenage smartphone use are unrealistic and potentially harmful.
- The UK government has commissioned Orben to review the effects of smartphones on teenagers as part of a broader initiative by the Department for Science, Innovation and Technology.
- Ministers have resisted implementing new legal restrictions beyond the current Online Safety Act, which targets harmful content.
- Orben's recent paper in the British Medical Journal suggests that bans are unlikely to work and calls for phone-free spaces instead.
- The paper argues that technology use offers benefits, including information access and social support, and that a one-size-fits-all approach to bans is not effective.
- Concerns were raised about the effects of trending content on vulnerable children and the need for a balanced approach to digital literacy and platform safety.
- The discussion around smartphone use for teenagers has intensified following cultural portrayals of its impacts in media, such as the Netflix drama 'Adolescence'.

items.title: Meta faces £1.8bn lawsuit over claims it inflamed violence in Ethiopia
Don’t weaken online safety laws for UK-US trade deal, campaigners urge
items.summary:
- Child safety campaigners warn government against weakening landmark online laws in UK-US trade deal.
- Molly Rose Foundation expresses dismay, calling potential compromise an 'appalling sellout'.
- The Online Safety Act aims to protect under-18s from harmful content and imposes heavy fines on violators.

items.title: The best walking pads and under-desk treadmills, tried and tested to turn your workday into a workout
items.summary:
- Public Health England recommends 10 minutes of brisk walking daily for health benefits.
- Walking pads can help integrate physical activity into desk jobs, allowing users to walk while working.
- Key findings from testing five walking pads:
  - **Best overall:** [JTX MoveLight](https://www.jtxfitness.com/jtx-movelight-walking-treadmill) - £499, known for build quality and performance.
  - **Best budget:** [Rattantree shock-absorbing treadmill](https://www.debenhams.com/product/rattantree-electric-shock-absorbing-treadmill_p-7cddfa07-d5bd-4177-ac92-a1511ca7eb66?colour=Black) - £142.49, basic features but lightweight.
  - **Best foldable:** [BodyMax WP60](https://www.amazon.co.uk/BodyMax-WP60-Treadmill-Walking-Pad/dp/B09XDXGHW3) - £549, high build quality and functionality.
  - **Best for incline:** [Mobvoi Home Treadmill Plus](https://www.mobvoi.com/uk/products/mobvoihometreadmillplus) - £224.99, offers incline options.

items.title: I got to play Nintendo Switch 2: hands-on with 2025’s gaming must-have
items.summary:
- Nintendo presents its new console, the Switch 2, following a successful hour-long live stream.
- Hands-on experience included four hours of gameplay showcasing titles like **Mario Kart World** and **Super Mario Party Jamboree**.
- **Mario Kart World** features a new Knockout Tour mode with 24 racers and a battle royale feel.
- **Super Mario Party Jamboree** emphasizes local multiplayer, utilizing a camera and microphone for interactive games.
- The Switch 2 is an iterative upgrade focusing on improved functionality and design, including more durable Joy-Cons and a larger screen.
- Performance impressions suggest efficient loading times and smooth gameplay across various titles, including *Cyberpunk* and *Zelda: Breath of the Wild*.

items.title: Trapped with a Tesla: my dream car has become a living nightmare
items.summary:
- The author and spouse bought a Tesla Model S after their children left home, initially excited by the technology.
- Tesla sales dropped by 13% early in 2025, prompting protests against CEO Elon Musk.
- The author enjoyed using the car for road trips across Europe but later felt uncomfortable with Musk's right-wing political views.
- Tesla owners expressed discomfort in online communities, leading to a sense of isolation for the author.
- The author's daughter suggested selling the Tesla due to diminishing resale value, but they feel trapped with the car for now.

items.title: Block-busted: why homemade Minecraft movies are the real hits
items.summary:
- Minecraft has over 204 million monthly active players and has generated over $3bn in revenue since its release in 2011.
- The trailer for the live-action *A Minecraft Movie* received negative feedback, with over 1 million downvotes within three days.
- Fans are creating their own animated trailers that better reflect the game's unique aesthetic, like the trailer by YouTuber ElVitt0ri0.
- The movie's production faced multiple directorial changes, and the final product is criticized for not capturing the essence of Minecraft as a sandbox game.

items.title: Shenmue voted the most influential video game of all time in Bafta poll
items.summary:
- Shenmue, a 1999 Dreamcast game, was voted the most influential video game of all time in a Bafta poll.
- The poll placed Doom (1993) at second and Super Mario Bros (1985) at third.
- Shenmue is recognized for its unique blend of RPG elements with life simulation, introducing many gameplay conventions still in use today.
- Despite initial financial failure, the game's cultural impact and nostalgia contributed to its recognition.
- Other games on the top list include Half-Life, Minecraft, and The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time.

items.title: How Afrofuturism can help us imagine futures worth living in | Lonny Avi Brooks and Reynaldo Anderson
Floppy disks and vaccine cards: exhibition tells tale of privacy rights in UK
items.summary:
- An exhibition by the Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO) opened in Manchester, featuring 40 items illustrating the evolution of data privacy.
- Items include a Pokémon toy, floppy disk, Tesco Clubcard, and Covid vaccination card.
- The ICO, founded 40 years ago, regulates data protection and faces challenges in keeping up with rapid technological changes.

items.title: ‘Meta has stolen books’: authors to protest in London against AI trained using ‘shadow library’
items.author: Kate Mosse, Tracy Chevalier, Daljit Nagra, AJ West, Richard Osman, Kazuo Ishiguro, Val McDermid, Anna Ganley
items.summary:
- Authors and publishing professionals are protesting outside Meta’s London office against the use of copyrighted books for AI training.
- Key attendees include authors Kate Mosse, Tracy Chevalier, and poet Daljit Nagra.
- The Society of Authors is hand-delivering a letter to Meta, asserting their stance against copyright infringement.
- Meta allegedly used the ‘shadow library’ LibGen, which has over 7.5 million books for AI training.
- The protest highlights the legal and ethical implications of using copyrighted material without permission.
- A petition with 7,000 signatures calls for UK government accountability in this matter.
- Demonstrators plan to use hashtags like #MetaBookThieves and #MakeItFair during the protest.

items.title: A Minecraft Movie review – building-block game franchise spin-off is rollicking if exhausting fun
items.summary:
- The film is set in the Minecraft world and is a comedy-fantasy adventure suitable for almost all ages.
- Jack Black plays Steve, while Jason Momoa portrays Garrett “The Garbage Man” Garrison.
- The film features secondary characters like Henry, Natalie, and Dawn, though they struggle to shine beside Black and Momoa.
- Jennifer Coolidge delivers a memorable performance as a teacher character, showcasing her comedic talent.
- While the film has standout performances, the storytelling is criticized for lacking cohesion and depth, affecting its overall impact.

items.title: Everything we learned from Nintendo’s ‘deep dive’ into the Switch 2
items.summary:
- Nintendo launched the Switch 2, a refined version of the original console, with enhancements discussed in a livestream.
- Key features include:
  - A larger 7.9-inch full HD display (1080p).
  - Redesigned Joy-Con controllers with larger buttons and a rollerball for mouse-like functionality.
- New game announcements include Mario Kart World, featuring open-world gameplay, endurance races, and 24-player capacity.
- A GameChat facility on Joy-Con enables group discussions and video chats during gameplay.
- Launching at £395.99, with Mario Kart World costing £75, fans are concerned about pricing and availability.

items.title: Nintendo reveals Switch 2 console due to launch on 5 June
Ed Atkins review – a harrowing medley of spiders, sinkholes and death
items.summary:
- Ed Atkins' exhibition at Tate Britain blends laughter and pain, dealing with themes of death and existence.
- The exhibition features digital self-portrayals and surrealistic scenes, including a CGI-avatar swallowed by a sinkhole.
- Elements from the exhibition include piles of objects falling down, emotional piano performances, and a video based on Atkins' father's diary, showcasing themes of illness and mortality.

items.title: What Australians flying to the US need to know about phone and device searches at the border
items.summary:
- Recent reports indicate that Australian travellers to the US may face searches of their devices at the border.
- A French scientist was denied entry after messages critical of Donald Trump were found on his phone.
- The US government can search devices on entry; refusing to consent may not prevent the search.
- Immigration officers can conduct thorough searches and may keep devices for prolonged periods if necessary.
- Travellers are advised to protect their devices by limiting stored information and considering the use of a 'burner' phone.
- It is recommended to travel with as little information as possible and employ strong passwords.
- Australian Border Force officers have similar powers to US officers regarding device searches.

items.title: Tesla quarterly sales slump 13% amid backlash against Elon Musk
Italian police increase security at Tesla dealerships after 17 cars destroyed in Rome fire
items.summary:
- 17 Tesla cars were destroyed in a fire at a dealership in Torre Angela, Rome.
- Italian police are investigating if the fire was started by anarchists, with heightened security measures recommended at all Tesla dealerships in Italy.
- Musk labeled the incident as "terrorism" on social media and linked it to a global wave of vandalism against Tesla.
- Tesla dealerships in Italy are under threat amidst the backdrop of political activism and protests related to Musk's political activities in the US, including a boycott movement.
- Similar vandalism incidents occurred in Germany and Sweden, while prominent political figures in Italy expressed solidarity with Musk.

items.title: Roblox gives parents more power over children’s activity on gaming platform
items.summary:
- Parents can block their children from communicating with specific friends or playing certain games on Roblox.
- Three new safety tools are available for parents who verify their identity with ID or credit card.
- The updates include friend management, content maturity level control, and screen-time insights.
- New regulations under the Online Safety Act require tech companies to address harmful content or face penalties.
- Roblox has faced reports of bullying and inappropriate content, especially affecting users aged 8 to 12.
- Roblox’s chief safety officer emphasizes the company's commitment to safety.
- In 2024, Roblox averaged over 80 million daily players, with 40% under the age of 13.
- Previous updates have included preventing users under 13 from sending direct messages.
- Concerns remain regarding the presence of harmful content despite safety improvements.

items.title: Trump to consider final proposal on TikTok future as US ban deadline looms
items.summary:
- Donald Trump is set to review a final proposal regarding TikTok before the deadline for a sale to a non-Chinese buyer.
- Key officials, including US vice-president JD Vance and commerce secretary Howard Lutnick, will meet to discuss TikTok’s future.
- Trump indicated that a deal with ByteDance, the parent company of TikTok, should be finalized before Saturday's deadline.
- The proposed deal involves significant investment from firms like Andreessen Horowitz and Blackstone to increase non-Chinese ownership of TikTok.
- A US ban on TikTok is poised to take effect due to national security concerns unless a sale occurs.

items.title: UK needs to relax AI laws or risk transatlantic ties, thinktank warns
items.summary:
- Tony Blair’s thinktank urges UK to relax copyright laws for AI firms to innovate.
- Strict copyright measures could strain UK-US relations as US plans to announce tariffs on UK goods.
- The report states UK privacy laws must align with US policies to avoid pushing AI development abroad.
- TBI supports proposals allowing AI training on copyright-protected material without permission unless creators opt out.
- Warns UK could weaken its position in the AI race if it enforces overly restrictive laws compared to the EU, Japan, or Singapore.
- Calls for the establishment of a Centre for AI and Creative Industries to bridge the gap between tech and creative sectors.
- Criticism from campaigners about potential conflicts of interest due to TBI’s funding from US tech billionaire Larry Ellison.

items.title: Pupils in England to be taught about online spending and scams
items.summary:
- New financial literacy lessons for pupils aged 5-16 in England to address online spending and risks associated with in-game purchases.
- The curriculum includes 80 lessons developed by the Oak National Academy to help children understand money management and distinguish between wants and needs.
- Reports highlight concerning trends, such as children unintentionally racking up large bills on purchases, with one child reportedly spending over £8,500 on the Apple app store.
- Primary lessons focus on basic financial concepts, while secondary resources cover topics like inflation, cryptocurrency, and how to analyze advertising claims.
- Calls for improved financial education have been echoed by parents and experts to prepare children for adult financial challenges.

items.title: Data protection bill leaves room for governmental abuse, campaigners warn
items.summary:
- Privacy campaigners warn that new data protection laws could misuse voters' personal data for political targeting.
- Critics, including the Open Rights Group, raise concerns about 'Henry VIII powers' that allow government discretion in using data with minimal checks.
- The proposed bill, effective early 2026, may eliminate essential risk assessments and adequate parliamentary oversight on data use for campaigning.
- Campaigners argue clear, fair rules are vital for democratic integrity and preventing potential future abuse by governments.

items.title: How Tesla became a battleground for political protest
items.summary:
- Protests against Elon Musk and Tesla occurred globally over the weekend, aiming to influence US political democracy.
- One protest sign in Manhattan read: "Burn a Tesla, save democracy."
- Demonstrators are not against electric cars but Musk's political alliances, notably with Donald Trump.
- Despite hundreds gathering, the protests did not have large turnouts.
- Musk's wealth dropped over $100bn as Tesla's stock value fell nearly 50% since December 2024.
- Tesla owners face pressure to either support or condemn Musk due to his political actions.
- The ongoing political controversy is impacting consumer sentiment toward Tesla.
